title: Cylinder Head Description

body.body: The engine is fitted with an aluminium alloy cylinder head, which carries the camshafts, valves and spark plugs. The cylinder head is cast as a single entity and various components are permanently added after machining.
The camshafts run directly in the cylinder head without separate bearings. Valve clearances are adjusted by changing variable thickness shims which sit between the follower and the valves.
Each pair of followers are secured to the cylinder head by a shaft which is secured by a plug and seal.
The camshafts are driven by a silent-type chain. The chain is guided by two blades and is tensioned by a hydraulic tensioner.
The camshaft drive chain tensioner is spring operated. The spring pressure pushes the plunger against the tensioner blade which tensions the camshaft drive chain.
Oil is supplied to the cylinder head by internal drillings. When the oil is supplied to the cylinder head, it is distributed along further internal drilling’s within the head casting and cam ladder.
Single valve springs are used to close both the exhaust valves and the inlet valves.

These valve springs have tapered coils at one end to assist in the prevention of valve bounce at high engine speed and to give a smooth valve actuation. When assembling the cylinder head it is important that the smaller diameter wound ends of the springs are fitted upwards (towards the camshafts). The tip of the inlet and exhaust valves are hardened to give a long service life.
Due to the methods used to assemble the valve seat and valve guides to the head, these parts cannot be replaced.

In any of the following operations that necessitate the removal or disconnection of the camshaft drive chain, NEVER turn the engine without the camshaft drive chain and tensioner correctly fitted and adjusted. In the disassembled condition, the pistons will contact the valves if the crankshaft is turned, causing severe engine damage.
